page.title: 01Kiers Hill,West of Waterside
page.content: This is a windswept upland area, formerly almost entirely comprising rough grazing, but radically changed from 1980-85 by the afforestation of the western parts of Sitka spruce, an exotic conifer species from canada. The young forest still looks like overgrown and unused grazing land as no trees are yet more than two metres high. The eastern half of the block is still dominated by rough grazing land which supports black face sheep and some 'store'cattle in the summer. Wire fences have replaced dykes and hedges for stock control and broadleaf trees are becoming scarcer aroud Kiers Farm. Waterside suffers high unemployment and has a largely aged population. The old slag heaps of a former iron works are curetnly being landscaped into more pleasing shapes and reseeded with grass. Te railway sidings are used
